Whither Tradition?
Concerning the query in regard to the alleged list
of regulations set forth in the Handbook, the Council replied:
"The ten things listed are merely traditions. The
Student Council did not sanction the publishing of
these as their imposed duties on Freshmen."
In other words the page which has appeared in the
handbook, given to practically every student, is without
foundation in regard to any Student Council enforcement
of their "duties." The Student Council recognizes them
only as traditions.
To discuss them now, we will reprint the ten in full:
1. Freshmen and Sophomores must attend the assemblies held Thursday at 11.30 twice a month.
2. Freshmen are expected to read the Constitution of
the Student Council in order to familiarize themselves
with the forms of student government at Hopkins.
Copies of this Constitution may be obtained at the post
office.
3. Freshmen shall possess copies of the Hopkins Songbook and the Y. M. C. A. Handbook.
4. Freshmen shall at once learn the University songs
and yells found in this Handbook and shall be familiar
with them by the time of the organization of their class.

Be There Tonight
Judging from reactions and comments of those who
have been following the progress of the Hopkins Musical
Club for several years, tonight's Home Concert should be
an unusually enjoyable evening of music.
To those of you who want to hear some really fine
singing of Hopkins songs—to hear "Dear Old Johnny
Hopkins" with soft lights and clear harmonious, and
unified male voices—and who desire to listen to the
varied repertoire of other songs from "I Love Life" to
the "Lord's Prayer" and three sea chanties, come tonight and witness one of the finest Glee Clubs since
Wilson's time.
For those who like string selections, there will be
Gelri's Banjo Club and Hawaiian Troupe, who will pick
rhythmically to the strains of the stirring J.H.U. March
and haunting Hawaiian tunes. It will be a treat merely
watching Gelri plunk away or Don Hamilton wiggling in
rhythm.
Of course, there will be the usual collegiate quartette
—only with a varied group of novelty arrangements.
Gelri's son, Conrad, equally gifted in musical talent, will
be "tops" for tonight's performance. The Blue Jays
have all their instruments tuned for some sweet orchestral selections.
There is really an excellent program on tap tonight,
and every student should support this activity for a
full evening's enjoyment.

On Some Facts
In our editorial a propos the dormitory incident we
asked: "Where was the Student Council?"
Having since been before the Council, we were enlightened thusly:
On Friday, February 12, the day copies of the disturbing letters were sent to the Student Council, Milton
Hutchcraft (Freshman representative) called Hershner
Cross (Council president) and they planned to see Mr.
Saurwein Saturday. At dinner Friday night announcement of this plan was given to the entire dormitory by
Hutchcraft.
Saturday Mr. Saurwein and Dean Berry not in. Monday at ten o'clock, Mr. Cross again was unable to see
Mr. Saurwein and there was also a fruitless four o'clock
visit. Tuesday afternoon, the sixteenth, Cross was infromed with details that the affair was settled, although
a Council meeting was scheduled for Wednesday at
four o'clock to make recommendations and settlements.
"We thought there was nothing else to be done."

More Of The Council
Perhaps the most important comment we have to
make would be embodied in a statement made by one
who witnessed the entire proceedings and attend all
the meetings from the beginning of the adjustment to
suggestion until the final settlement:
"The matter was settled completely without aid or
suggestion until the final settlement:
This has been verified by the dorm residents interviewed as well as by Dr. Andrews, Head Proctor, who
was in a great measure responsible for the smooth
solution of the affair. Thus, acceptance of the above actions of the Student Council notwithstanding, the results
of this activity was fruitless. The quotaion from an
authoritative sousre quoted above suffices to support
this.
But deeper consideration of this whole problem indicates that the Student Council, guardian of the Honor
System, might have prevented any trouble at all at the
dormitory by building up respect for the Honor System
among the residents. After all, all students ----- including
the dorme s — are responsible to the Student Council
in a violation of the Honor System.
Thus we feel that any fine or penalty should not
have been imposed apparently indiscriminately —by
University officials, but by the Student Council. Surely
the understanding of the problem and its solution should
best be decided by a student representative body.
As far as the actions cited by the Student Council
are concerned, it appears that the Council apparently
tried to do something. But the fact remains that they
contributed nothing to the adjustment; independent dormitory residents and Dr. Andrews worked out the
solution.
For the future, the committee appointed by Dr.
Andrews will set up plans. We hope they will work
out a suitable method of solution. We hope that the
Student Council will cooperate with it.

5. Freshmen shall not wear hats inside of the University buildings.
6. Freshmen shall occupy seats in the rooter's section
at all games at Homewood, unless accompanied by
guests.
In any event, all other regulation shall be in force
whice Freshmen are escorting guests.
7. All Freshmen must speak to all members of the
faculty and upper clansmen who pass them on University
property.
8. No Freshman shall wear, while on University property, any letter or insignia of any kind won at another
Institution.
Obviously, the first is temporarily suspended while the
plan suggested by the NEWS-LETTER is being tried out
under the active direction of the Student Council. Thus
far this method of voluntary assemblies with an attractive roster of speakers is receiving popular and enthusiastic support. We will discuss this more fully n a
subsequent editorial.
As for the rest, we might as well face reality; are
these traditions being followed by Hopkins students?
We might as well admit it: No! Freshmen, almost without exception obey few if any of these so-called traditions.
Well, is this an evil situation or not? Should there be
any enforcement at all by the logical body -- the
Sudent Council?
While all these things are, in the main, superficial
features of college life, we still feel that they help in
making one's stay at the Hopkins more colorful and
pleasant. They aid in building up that spirit — so undesirable in excess and so stupid if made dominant — yet
helpful when properly blended with a well-rounded college life.
We believe that these Freshman duties should be revived and made widespread. We pledge ourselves to do
all we can to accomplish this; we ask your cooperation.

CURBING THE COURT
By WILLIAM DIAMOND
A little history might not be considered inappropriate in re the much
discussed plan presented by President
Roosevelt for the reform of the Supreme Court.
"We are aware of the blind veneration which has heretofore sealed the
eyes of a very large proportion of the
public, whenever their looks have been
directed towards that sacro-sanct tribunal (the Supreme Court), in prostrate submission to its presumed infallibility; and, in discussing our subject with the freedom Which it demands, many a reader may perhaps
hold up his hands in holy horror at
this impious temerity. But this abject
mental subjection to authority and assumption is unworthy equally of our
country and age . . . The noblest and
best of institutions can be preserved
in their purity only by the perpetual
vigilance of public opinion. Their
best friends are those who most
frankly and freely agitate the frequent
discussion of the first principles on
which they were founded . and those
who would inculcate that blind veneration and submission to which we have
alluded, and thus leave free scope to
the gradual development of those
abuses which seem inseparable from
the practical workings of all institutions, are in truth their most dangerous enemies."
The above statement was made by
no socialist, visionary Utopian, or
Marxist in depreciation of our Federal
Judiciary. It appeared in January,
1838, just one hundred years ago, in
a conservatice States' Rights journal.
The Unitekl States Magazine and
Democratic Review, a periodical devoted to the exaltation of the American democracy. Judging by the tone
of the journal, the opinion it expressed
on the sanctity of the Supreme Court
was by no means uncommon at that
time. In the 100 years which have
racy, of education and of political
elapsed, despite the spread of democknowledge, that opinion has become
not only unfashionable, but sacrilege
as well.
No man presents a plan for changing, no matter how mildly, the arrangement of the Supreme Court without having the epithets of "radical," or
"dictator" shouted at him from every
corner of the nation. No man presents a plan to remedy the one outstanding weakness of the Supreme
